passage_text: Mea culpa is a Latin phrase that translates into English as my mistake or my fault. To emphasize the message, the adjective maxima may be inserted, mea maxima culpa, which translates as my most [grievous] fault.. From our Multilingual Translation Dictionary. 1  mea culpa Catalan, Valencian. 2  moje vina, moje chyba Czech. 3  meine Schuld, mea culpa German. 4  ήμαρτον Greek. 5  mea culpa French. 6  טעות שלי Hebrew. 7  ჩემი ბრალია Georgian. 8  моя вина Russian. 9  moja greška Serbo-Croatian. 10  benim hatam Turkish.

Meaning. I'm to blame. The literal translation from the Latin is 'through my own fault'. Even those who don't speak Latin could probably make a guess that this phrase means 'I am culpable', or words to that effect. Confiteor Deo omnipotenti, beatae Beatæ mariae Mariæ, semper Virgini Beato, michaeli Michæli Archangelo, beato Ioanni Baptistae baptistæ Sanctis, apostolis Petro, et paulo, omnibus (sanctis et vobis), fratres et tibi pater, quia peccavi nimis: cogitatione verbo, et opere, mea culpa mea. culpa mea maxima culpa

However, particularly in a situation where someone repeatedly commits a sin which is addictive in nature, or where someone's life situation means that they suffer for reasons that are not their own fault, it might lead to an exaggeration in the sense of sin, a sense of guilt in the unhealthy meaning of that word. through my fault, through my fault, through my most grievous fault The effect of this when it is prayed within the context of Night Prayer, and immediately following an examination of conscience, is interesting.

Mea culpa. I'm to blame. The literal translation from the Latin is 'through my own fault'. Even those who don't speak Latin could probably make a guess that this phrase means 'I am culpable', or words to that effect. Confiteor Deo omnipotenti, beatae Beatæ mariae Mariæ, semper Virgini Beato, michaeli Michæli Archangelo, beato Ioanni Baptistae baptistæ Sanctis, apostolis Petro, et paulo, omnibus (sanctis et vobis), fratres et tibi pater, quia peccavi nimis: cogitatione verbo, et opere, mea culpa mea. culpa mea maxima culpa

It is mEa culpa, and it means my fault/ crime/ sin/ offense/ guilt. It was used in the Latin mass, in the communal act of contrition. · just now. Report Abuse. 'Mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa.' 'Through my fault, through my fault, through my most grievous fault.' Part of the Catholic liturgy-the English version is used by Anglo-Catholics. cymry3jones · 8 years ago.

According to Adrian Fortescue, the inclusion in the Confiteor of the phrase mea culpa can be traced back only to the 16th century. However, the Latin phrase mea culpa was used, even in an English context, earlier than that. Although the Confiteor was not then part of the Mass, it was used in administering the sacrament of Penance. In some forms it already included the phrase mea culpa. Thus the 9th-century Paenitentiale Vallicellanum II had a thrice-repeated mea culpa (without maxima) in its elaborate form of the Confiteor.

In catechesis, one can point out that mea culpa, mea culpa, mea maxima culpa is followed by the prayer of the priest which asks for God's mercy, His forgiveness of our sins and that He will lead us to eternal life. The reality of sin is more than matched by the reality of Divine Mercy. through my fault, through my fault, through my most grievous fault The effect of this when it is prayed within the context of Night Prayer, and immediately following an examination of conscience, is interesting.

Look up mea culpa in Wiktionary, the free dictionary. Mea culpa is a Latin phrase that means through my fault and is an acknowledgement of having done wrong. Grammatically, meā culpā is in the ablative case, with an instrumental meaning. The phrase comes from a prayer of confession of sinfulness, known as the Confiteor, used in the Roman Rite at the beginning of Mass or when receiving the sacrament of Penance. Although the Confiteor was not then part of the Mass, it was used in administering the sacrament of Penance. In some forms it already included the phrase mea culpa. Thus the 9th-century Paenitentiale Vallicellanum II had a thrice-repeated mea culpa (without maxima) in its elaborate form of the Confiteor.
under cover of the MEA CULPA, striking her breast so vigorously that everybody, even the lady with the red cushion, turned round toward her. The Three Musketeers by Dumas, Alexandre View in context.
